raw_comment:
What do you notice?
When it comes to comparing students with the same test scores and figuring out who to admit to an elite college, legacy applicants have a much better chance of getting admitted. But, when money is added to the picture, non-legacy applicants that come from poorer families have a higher chance of being admitted than wealthy non-legacy applicants.
What do you wonder?
I wonder why the colleges pay attention to the students' background and income more than their test scores. If a non-legacy student had a higher test score than a legacy student would it convince the colleges to admit them over the legacy student?
How does this relate to you and your community?
This relates to me because I am currently in high school and I will start preparing for college some time next year, and if I'm not a legacy student, or a poor non-legacy student, but I still get good test scores, will I have a good chance of getting admitted?
Create a catchy headline that captures the graphâ€™s main idea.
"Dear my future College, am I good enough for you?"
ace_sentences: Some students have the same test scores.
An elite college must decide which student to admit.
A legacy applicant has a better chance of admission than a non-legacy applicant who has the same test score.
Some non-legacy applicants come from poorer families.
Some non-legacy applicants come from wealthy families.
A non-legacy applicant from a poorer family has a higher chance of admission than a wealthy non-legacy applicant.
I wonder why colleges pay more attention to a student's background and income than to a student's test scores.
A non-legacy student can have a higher test score than a legacy student.
I wonder if a higher test score would convince a college to admit the non-legacy student instead of the legacy student.
I am currently in high school.
Next year I will start preparing for college.
I may be a non-legacy student.
I may be not a poor non-legacy student.
I can get good test scores.
I wonder if I will have a good chance of admission.
The headline is: Dear my future college, am I good enough for you?
